comments.commentBody:
As a current graduate student and soon to be father, I look at this issue from both the perspective of a participant in the hysteria-driven education system and soon to be helpless-observer of the same.

When I was in high school, I tried to take only the APs that really interested me, but eventually succumbed to the pressure of trying to pad my GPA with weighted courses. The hysteria of college applications demanded it then and it is only worse today. I knew people then who realized that working so hard was only worth it if you had a goal in mind, and had a realistic shot of achieving it. I was lucky in that my leap panned out. But in the modern America, it is too easy to forget that life need not depend on the 4.8 weighted gpa with magna cum laude from an Ivy and a graduate or doctoral degree from a similar institution in order to be happy–which ultimately must be the goal if we are to have a society worth sustaining. The academic achievement track is useful for a particular class of jobs, for a particular class of life, but it is not the only way to be happy.

In raising my child(ren), I will try to help them understand that it must be their own conscious choice to walk that path, and that they do have other options–other options as simple as not taking AP courses. They won't ruin their lives if they can't get into a top 10 college; it just means they have to be more creative.

"His bold stand seems all the more striking in today’s atmosphere, in which moral courage among the very prominent — the kind of courage that carries real risk — seems mostly to have disappeared."

It is the truth of this statement that brings me closer to despair right now than at any previous time I can bring to mind. Mr Herbert is right to remind us of Dr King's courageous stand; but Dr King would surely be the first to acknowledge that he was not alone among "very prominent" Americans in 1967. In 2009 he would be - ALONE - ALL ALONE. What has become of our beloved country?

The "homework" is busy-work of the must absurd kind. Posters and "art" pieces, ridiculous "worksheets" that don't reflect the subject, consuming and irritating gobs of stupid memorization of non-relevant items. K-12, to put it bluntly, is a bunch of useless "facts" dressed up as curriculum.

My daughter said "enough" in 7th grade - and I put her in community college. Yes, the courses were twice as fast as high school courses (and 4x faster than middle school limbo). Yes, she had to keep up, write papers, complete assignments, go to office hours and take exams. Yes, it was college credit, so she couldn't slack off.

But she's now a Berkeley Regents and Chancellor's Scholar and actively involved in research.

Had two older siblings go to one of the "top" high schools in CA and I watched the schools devolve to worthless cramming as a feint to claims of academic rigor. Yes, it was pushed by the parents eager to get their kid into Berkeley or Stanford.

But glitter on posters and memorizing history dates does nothing for comprehension, content and critical thinking - and these are given short shrift in high schools. And even our tip-top affluent high school did *not* have PhD instructors like she had at community college - they have some pretty good BAs from Cal State (and some really mediocre ones). She got excellent science lab instruction BTW - AP classes in chem and biology are not considered substitutes for 6+ hrs/wk labtime so students have to take the intro classes again.

Finally, none of that absurd bullying that parents think is "socialization". The people in calculus, physics, biology, chemistry, history, polisci, English and music were much much nicer because the jerks dropped the course.

You mean they're using iterns like college basketball players who rake in millions to their institutions, on the off chance they'll get a degree or opportunity to play in a foreign league or NBA if they stay healthy?

Why is the government allowed to hire unpaid interns? Seems inherently unfair from the student perspective. If you genuinely want to experience work in the private sector, but cannot get credit from your school, you can't get the experience that you desire. This policy oddly favors the not too bright who attend institutions that liberally award academic credit for internships and simultaneously favors those who can afford to work for 3 months without compensation.
NO NO. america is a country of laws and employers are all honourable......
I believe this may fall in the "DUH" category.
oh please, at least they see what it is like to actually have to go to work.

In social work school, there are no unpaid internships. The student pays to work. One must complete the field placements. The field placements earn college credits. The student pays the prevailing per credit charge. Most agencies could not exist without these students because they couldn't afford to pay regular paid workers.

Unpaid = 21st century slave labor.

Speaking as a retire labor lawyer, it would be bloody near impossible to set up an internship that was not for college credit and get away without paying the worker. And make no mistake, these interns are workers.

Corporate USA is near realizing its ultimate dream of reducing what it has to pay in wages -- free work would suit corporate greed perfectly.

(PS: I wouldn't hire anyone who worked as an intern for free. They would be simply too stupid to live if they would agree to that.)
Unpaid internships take advantage of students .......... I wonder how many interns in the US Congress, State Legislatures, etc. are unpaid.

This whole article is a laugh. What do you think Washington, DC has been running on for decades? There is an army of unpaid and underpaid interns here. These kids might get travel stipends, but they barely cover that cost. Interns here don't get any money for food either.

Strangely, I haven't heard of a crackdown on unpaid interns in DC. Then again, a lot of Washingtonians look the other way for many shady things here.

This is so true!!  When I was in college, many of my peers took full-time, 40+ hour a week, completely unpaid "internships" for the entire summer.  I enviously saw them toil in their chosen field for no money, while I was desperate to get any job I could that would pay my rent and bills, as I was responsible for ALL of my own costs in college - rent, food, bills, and tuition.  Of course I had loans and some small scholarships to contribute, but still needed to work full-time while attending school and 60-70 hrs a week in the summer just to pay bills.  While I got real-world experience in a managerial position, which admittedly was not anywhere "prestigious", my friends swept floors, took out the garbage, and played computer games at big name firms for free.  While I am sure my experience was far more educational and informative to the business world than theirs was, of course their connections through the glamorous world of unpaid internships got them much farther than my "real job" did.  No wonder everyone thinks 20somethings have a terrible work ethic...
Very meaningful prediction for the Giants' play this year. Thanks.

RCRogers3:

Our Airborne troops in WWII charged across open fields in Europe as a tactic against against Germans with rifles and automatic weapons. I believe the special forces now employ a similar tactic when they are engaged by superior numbers. It involves a reflex type assault with a huge burst of automatic weapons. If Marines employ similar tactics it is because all assault type troops know they are safest when they are mobile and attacking in many situations. If Airborne troops could use this tactic against trained German soldiers with accurate rifles it could be used against Taliban militia. The real issue is U.S. troops would be more at risk from Taliban with rifles on auto closer in but U.S. troops should still prevail in closer shot out because of superior auto fire training. Would the advantage be worth the extra casualties? In the long term yes because the best way to counter insurgents is not to do predictable things on any level over the long term.

In the Pacific the Japanese used a similar reflex assault tactic on patrol and suffered high casualties because U.S. troops would set up machine gun ambushes initiated by rifle fire to lure the charging Japanese in. So such a tactic should just be one of many that a commander can call on and not be used all the time.

I agree with you about Motors. The only issue that need to be dealt with is the huge amount of supply and protective gear our troops now have to hump around with. Since so few of our troops are getting injured from rifle fire they should be allowed to travel with reduced amour and perhaps even no helmets, and transfer some of that weight to mortar rounds and tubes and extra sniper rifles etc.

There are many Afghans that can shoot accurately for the same reason stated above, survival hunting. The Taliban is not in general made up of these individuals today (thankfully for our grunts and jar-heads). As far as accuracy the AK is accurate enough in the hands of a trained individual but let us hope that there are not to many Nagants laying around as they are accurate and in the hands of a subsistence hunter... deadly

htpp://auto-parts-mall.net (printing)
Has anyone considered the role or influence the popy fields have on the fighting. Remember what the U.S. did in Vietnam with agent orange. Do the drug warlords get afree pass over there too?

Danielle (#9):
"We should be spending our time talking about the ways to end war rather than sexualizing the tools of war."

Huh?

Sexualizing?

I think you read a different article than the one the rest of us did.
Be careful - you can run into all sort of weird stuff on these internets.

It is a good point about how the Taliban (and associated groups, don't forget that not all insurgents are the same) make up for their weaknesses, but don't forget that in a sense it doesn't matter what their combat effectiveness is. An insurgent does not win a war by being more able to fight than their enemy, an insurgent wins a war by continuing to fight after their enemy has stopped fighting. In that manner, the ability to fight is inconsequential compared to the fact that there is fighting.
Like Kobe is only fair at draining treys? Has alot more range than did His Airness, the so-called greatest to ever lace up!
The Smoke Tree Resort is the best kept secret in town. Call the family that runs it and avoid the hassel of the mega chains. Trees, grass and grace. That is we ever need.
Pure racism. I've never heard of anybody doing such a thing about white presidents.

His patients should be thanking God that Dr. Cassell has given them advance warning of his character.  If I were his patient, I'd be running away like the wind.  Turning people away based on their beliefs is one mm away from giving them bad care for the same reason.
Is this the rationing conservatives warned about?

Awesome, Thank God for Dr. Cassell.  Now I suppose he will have to worry that the politburo, I mean the Obama Administration will write a new law that forces him to work under their prescribed set of conditions.
